content:

title: Re: Keenn 2 and 3 and 5 and 6
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Uh-huh... you played all seven Keen games in one day without using cheat codes[hr][/quote]
Almost feasible, if you had lots of practice and sat at your PC for 8 to 12 hours with a large supply of cola and pizza.
[quote]Quote:[hr]and now you just HAPPENED to lose the exact four Keen games that can't be downloaded legally.[hr][/quote]
This arouses suspicion. Of course, it's possible that you managed to lose the entire series and then download Keen 1 and 4 (legally), but then couldn't get a copy of the episodes you mentioned.

If you want to download them without paying, then you're out of luck. Unless you somehow manage to provide us with a scanned copy of your license (which I doubt you would be able to do by now, whether it existed or not) then you'll have to go buy the CD. (Of course, you'll have to get Keen 6 off eBay because no-one sells it anymore)

title: well
content:
It's more of a moral quandry, really. If, in 1992, paid iD Software full price for the Commander Keen series of games, kept the original disks, and everything... but sometime in, say, 2004, my disks went bad (as poorly stored floppies often do), am I not justified in downloading the game off of the world wide web?

On one hand, technically I still have the disks, they're just not in usable form... on the other hand, there's no way I can really "prove" that other than sending them in to iD, and that is often more trouble than it's worth. But if I just download the games, I'm no better than any other pirate.

At this point, you can get all 5 games for like $10 grand total from either company's online store... if you still want to support an old series, it's really a drop in the bucket...

content:

title: Keen 5
content:
Is Keen 5 really not shareware? That's odd, because years ago I bought what was advertised at the time as the shareware version, and it doesn't mention anything in the game itself about being the full version...

And on that note I wouldn't exactly call downloading Keen 6 'stealing' - if you're willing to pay for it and you can't buy it, then making a copy is hardly unfair, especially as unlike "stealing" you don't remove the original (think about it - if someone breaks into your house and steals your TV that's theft because you no longer have a TV. But if someone looked in through your window and somehow made a copy of your TV for themselves leaving yours untouched, most people wouldn't have a problem with that.)

Anyway, if the cops do turn up on your doorstep the argument "But I *tried* to buy it" has to count for something...you can't refuse to accept someone's money and then claim that they never paid you...

title: Re: Keen 5
content:
Actually, I bought Keens 3 & 5 from a shareware vendor many years ago. I also bought Duke Nukum 3 (from the first trilogy) at a shareware vendor as well as Jill Saves The Prince (part three of 'Jill Of The Jungle).

However, the "second episode" of any game was never to be found at these vendors for some reason.

The only legally distributable versions of Commander Keen are episodes 1, 4, demo version of Keen 6 and shareware version of Keen Dreams (i've played the registered version of Keen Dreams and is virtually the same apart from the feeling that you've actually paid a few dollars for the damn game).[img]http://www.geocities.com/miniopolis/soul.txt[/img]
